This is one of the BEST Kairosoft games IMO. A great balance of all the elements that make this genre great (battle, development, building, strategy, etc). However, I must give 3 stars because the touch screen controls are not calibrated properly anymore. When I touch an area, the cursor selects just above where I touched. Maybe the controls need updated for newer devices? If the touch screen controls are fixed, I will change my review back to 5 stars where this great game belongs!

Absolutely love this game, cleverly combines turn based RPG combat and basic but enjoyable village management.  Easily the best Kairosoft game by far, really happy with how both my village and my heroes are evolving. The war stuff is a bit cut and dry, compared to the rest of the game I feel like it doesn't have as much depth. Basically, you either outnumber them and win, or you draw... No real tactics to play off of unfortunately, your heroes have 'some' influence over the battle, but not much in the grand scheme of things.  They could easily build upon several ideas presented in this game, and I hope they do because what they have so far is so much fun. Some of the village management could be improved, I felt the reason why some stores did well and others did not was totally arbitrary.

Kairosoft usually focuses on very similar gameplay and while familiar, Ninja Village is an interesting entry into their story games. Like all Kairosoft games you can't really fail, but here you can get better. There is a lot to experiment with, and a lot of strategies and options won't be known when you start which makes it more replayable than just knowing the right sales combos. Probably my favorite of their products.

Despite all its flaws, I couldn't put it down for months. The flaws come from a developer who spits out games a dime a dozen and consequently doesn't really finish them off very well; they lack polish. I've finally finished playing now, and although I was glued to it for months and definitely got my money's worth, by the end I was pleased to "beat the game" and be able to stop. The fights are terrible: you can't contribute in any meaningful way and are obliged to just sit and wait it out.
Need I say more???

You start off with a handful of squares and ways to manipulate them, but complexity comes fast. (Along with a surplus of cool things you will never use). This is a great game for those that want a simpler Sid Meyers's Civilization-esque game and you don't like how the nearby nations meddle with your space. If you want to feel accomplished, this game is addicting, but like other Kairosoft games, they have limited replay value. Initial confusion leaves this game wanting of a stronger tutorial (wot 'str' do??)

It's no secret that Kairosoft make some of the very best games for the Android platform, and this is a fantastic one even by their high standards. Charming, easy to get to grips with and endlessly compulsive, there's a whole lot of game here for very little money. If you're looking to see what the fuss is about with Kairo's quirky little strategy games, I'd rate both this and Game Dev Story as absolutely essential.

I've enjoyed Game Dev Story and Dungeon Village, but this one just doesn't provide the same level of enjoyment. The city management is uninspiring, and the combat is somewhat repetitive. Everything seems right in this game. Love it very much!

Dungeon Villiage was my favorite, but this one tops it. It took me awhile to realize that the economy of this game wasn't based on abstract economic models but actually by simulating every single villager individually in its (oftentimes shortsighted) decisionmaking life. One of the many little gems hidden in this game. It's not hard, but gives the game connieseur a lot to play with. I'm not a japanophile, but this game has a sense of understated subtlety that you won't find in a lot of western indie games, which tend to be more "conceptual".
Another brilliant time eating game from Kairosoft. Still waiting on GDS2 though.

I lean more towards the "Adventure" Kairosoft games, I loved Dungeon Village and this is very similar to that one.  Requires lots of strategy involving village prop placement and training/equiping villagers to do the  role they're best capable of doing.  My ONLY complaint is I wish the villager menu was more integrated.  I don't understand why "Training" is a separate menu.  When I'm viewing strength or equipment options, I'd like to be able to click "Train" from there, but can't.   Also when tapping on a villager,  you can't access "Train" from there.  You have to open the "Train" menu and find by name the villager you're interested in upgrading.  Other than that annoyance,  it's a really solid game.

.. but I'm very peturbed that they require you to beat each enemy in three rounds even though you clearly win. Even if there's just a single troop standing after three rounds than the whole battle is a wash. So the difficulty of the game stems from learning to kill them quickly, not so much strategically. Other than that it's a good Kairosoft game, a mixture of oh Edo village and epic astro story. I also feel the game should give you the ability to assign tasks to villagers. Not just plopping them down

I've been a fan of Kairosoft games for a year now and played through maybe 6 of their games, this is the best one yet. The town building side is better than Pocket Academy, Venture Towns, and Dungeon Village. Although the AI of the villages still often frustrates my. And the battle mechanics are cute and inviting yet surprising sophisticated just below the surface.  Great game, can't stop playing.
